title: Cannabis Intoxication: Clinical Patterns, Biomarkers and Risk Profiles
section: Understanding the Biological Signature of the Ayahuasca Experience
text:
Understanding the Biological Signature of the Ayahuasca Experience
Cannabis is often perceived as a ‚Äúsoft drug‚Äù. However, acute intoxication is an increasingly common reason for emergency department visits ‚Äî particularly with the rise of high-potency THC products, edibles and synthetic derivatives.
This project examines the clinical, biochemical and epidemiological features of acute cannabis intoxication in real-world healthcare settings, with the goal of understanding:

Who is most at risk
What biological systems are most affected
How clinical severity can be anticipated
What this tells us about cannabis as a pharmacological agent

Rather than focusing on social debate, this work approaches cannabis intoxication as a biomedical phenomenon.
Our 2025 study, published in nature neuropsychopharmacology, investigates these issues.

title: Cannabis Intoxication: Clinical Patterns, Biomarkers and Risk Profiles
text:
Why This Matters
Emergency departments are reporting increasing cases of:

Acute anxiety and panic reactions
Transient psychotic episodes
Cardiovascular symptoms (tachycardia, hypertension)
Altered consciousness
Accidental pediatric exposure
Poly-substance interactions

While most cases resolve without long-term consequences, some presentations mimic severe neurological or psychiatric disorders. Understanding the physiological signatures of intoxication helps clinicians differentiate between benign acute reactions and serious pathology.

title: B-HAPPY
text:
Overview
B-HAPPY (Barcelona Hormones And Pregnancy ‚Äì Pollution & Young Health) is an investigator-led research initiative examining how urban environmental exposure influences stress-related hormonal regulation during pregnancy and its downstream effects on maternal and infant health.
This project is the result of a collaboration between the Hospital del Mar Research Institute (HMRIB-IMIM) and the Barcelona Institute for Global Health(ISGlobal).
Funded through the Jove i Emergent programme of the Ajuntament de Barcelona, the project aims to consolidate a new independent research line at the intersection of environmental epidemiology, stress biology and computational biomedicine.

title: B-HAPPY
text:
Scientific Rationale
Urban environments expose populations to complex mixtures of:

Air pollution
Traffic-related emissions
Noise
Built-environment stressors

Pregnancy represents a biologically sensitive window during which environmental exposures may alter endocrine regulation, inflammatory pathways and metabolic adaptation.
Stress-related hormones ‚Äî particularly glucocorticoids and associated neuroendocrine mediators ‚Äî play a central role in:

Maternal physiological adaptation
Fetal development
Long-term neurodevelopmental trajectories

B-HAPPY investigates whether urban pollution contributes to measurable alterations in maternal stress biology and whether these changes are associated with maternal and infant health outcomes.

title: B-HAPPY
text:
Research Questions
The project addresses three core questions:

Does exposure to urban pollution correlate with altered maternal stress hormone profiles during pregnancy?

Are these biological alterations associated with obstetric or neonatal outcomes?

Can integrative modeling approaches identify vulnerability or resilience patterns within urban populations?

title: B-HAPPY
text:
Methodological Framework
B-HAPPY combines:

High-resolution environmental exposure assessment
Hormonal profiling during pregnancy
Clinical maternal‚Äìinfant phenotyping
Advanced statistical and machine learning models

The analytical framework integrates environmental data with biological measurements using reproducible computational pipelines in R and Python, ensuring methodological transparency and robustness.
Rather than focusing on single biomarkers, the project adopts a systems-level perspective to understand how environmental stressors may influence endocrine regulation during pregnancy.

title: B-HAPPY
text:
Innovation
What distinguishes B-HAPPY is the integration of:

Environmental epidemiology
Endocrine stress biology
Translational maternal health research
Computational modeling

By bridging environmental exposure data with biological stress markers, the project moves beyond associative epidemiology toward mechanistic insight.

title: B-HAPPY
text:
Public Health Relevance
Urban pollution is not evenly distributed across cities.
Understanding its biological impact during pregnancy has implications for:

Maternal health policy
Urban planning
Preventive public health strategies
Early-life health trajectories

B-HAPPY contributes evidence at a critical intersection:
where environmental design meets biological vulnerability.

title: B-HAPPY
text:
Broader Vision
Beyond immediate findings, the project establishes a framework for integrating environmental exposures into precision public health models.
It represents a step toward data-driven urban health research ‚Äî rigorous, computationally grounded and socially relevant.

title: about
text:
Welcome!
I am a biomedical scientist and computational biologist working at the intersection of metabolomics, neuroscience, environmental health and data science.
My path has taken me through the University of Alicante, University of Murcia, a small stay in Miami, University of Barcelona, Chalmers University of Technology, and the Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland ‚Äî a journey that has shaped both my scientific rigor and my ability to adapt, including to different climates, academic cultures, and, coffee and (green) tea standards.
I obtained my Ph.D.¬†in Health Sciences at the University of Barcelona (2017), where I specialized in biomarker discovery using untargeted metabolomics. My doctoral work involved designing human intervention studies, building laboratory SOPs, and leading data mining pipelines ‚Äî a period during which I learned that biological complexity is infinite and that spreadsheets, if not respected, can be dangerous.
During my postdoctoral training at the Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland and University College Dublin, I worked on multi-omics integration to investigate psychosis risk and nutritional biomarkers. This period consolidated my interest in systems-level thinking and in the interface between biology and computation.
Parallel to academia, I worked as a consultant at the Institute for Bioengineering of Catalonia (IBEC) in collaboration with Nestl√© Health Science, where I developed machine learning and signal-processing tools for biomarker discovery. This led to the development of an R package now available on GitHub and Bioconductor, and to the authorship of the Statistical Analysis Plan for a registered clinical trial. Industry taught me that rigor must coexist with deadlines.
I later joined the Hospital del Mar Research Institute (2020) through the competitive Juan de la Cierva program in biomedicine. There, I investigated on colorectal cancer, Alzheimer‚Äôs diesase, chronic kidney disease, by applying complex data-analyses and translating clinical language into scientific evidence through long training meetings with clinical staff in each therapeutic area. In collaboration with Maastricht University, I began working on human psychedelic research and the neurobiology of consciousness ‚Äî combining metabolomics, clinical phenotyping and connectomics derived from MRI of the central nervous system. This line of work continues today, exploring how altered states of consciousness can be studied through rigorous biological and computational frameworks.
My work spans neuroscience, oncology, epidemiology and Real-World Evidence methodologies ‚Äî always at the interface between statistics and medicine.
Currently, I work as a biostatistician at the Hospital del Mar Research Institute, where I lead a structural data analysis platform in ‚ÄúApplied Metabolomics‚Äù and co-direct a PhD thesis on early biomarkers of Alzheimer‚Äôs disease in the PREDIMED and PREDIMED-Plus cohorts. I am also Principal Investigator of the B-HAPPY project, funded by the Jove i Emergent program of the Barcelona City Council, investigating how urban pollution influences stress-related hormones during pregnancy and maternal‚Äìinfant health outcomes. The project reflects my broader interest in how environmental systems and biological systems continuously interact.
My research has been recognized with several awards, including:
I currently teach statistical learning and biostatistics at UPF, UB and IL3, where I try to convince students that p-values are not enemies but tools ‚Äî if treated with care.

text:
Science Communication
Beyond research, I am deeply committed to science communication.
I participate in a Pint of Science 2026 festival with the talk ‚ÄúLa bioqu√≠mica del bienestar‚Äù, and in the Festival de la Conciencia (FOC 2026) presenting ‚ÄúBrain-Body Integromics of the Ayahuasca Experience.‚Äù
My communication style combines methodological precision with intellectual curiosity and, when appropriate, a healthy sense of humor. Complex ideas deserve clarity ‚Äî and sometimes a well-timed joke.

Science is collaborative by nature. Whatever merit appears here is the result of mentors, students, colleagues and participants who generously shared their time and trust with me.
If any value has emerged from my work, may it contribute ‚Äî even in a small way ‚Äî to better understanding, better health, and wiser decisions.

title: Psychedelic Integromics Research
section: Understanding the Biological Signature of the Ayahuasca Experience
text:
Understanding the Biological Signature of the Ayahuasca Experience
Psychedelics are experiencing a scientific renaissance. While clinical trials suggest therapeutic potential in depression, PTSD and addiction, the biological mechanisms underlying their effects in humans remain largely unknown.
This project investigates one central question:

What happens in the human metabolome during a psychedelic experience?

Our 2022 study, published in Biomedicine & Pharmacotherapy, represents the first report describing the impact of a psychedelic (ayahuasca) on the human metabolome.

title: Psychedelic Integromics Research
text:
Why Ayahuasca?
Ayahuasca is a traditional Amazonian brew prepared from:

Banisteriopsis caapi (Œ≤-carbolines: harmine, harmaline, tetrahydroharmine)
Psychotria viridis (DMT)

DMT activates 5-HT2A receptors, while Œ≤-carbolines inhibit monoamine oxidase (MAO), allowing DMT to become orally active.
Although subjective effects are well described, the downstream biochemical cascades triggered by 5-HT2A activation remain poorly understood

title: Psychedelic Integromics Research
text:
Study Design
We conducted a within-subject observational study in 23 healthy participants from the Santo Daime tradition.

Plasma samples collected before and after ayahuasca intake
Targeted metabolomics via LC‚ÄìMS/MS
Subjective effects measured with the validated 5-D ASC scale
Integrated network modelling using regularized canonical correlation analysis (rCCA).
Pathway enrichment using diffusion-based KEGG analysis (FELLA)

This allowed us to connect:
Metabolites ‚ÜîÔ∏é Alkaloid concentrations ‚ÜîÔ∏é Subjective experience

title: Psychedelic Integromics Research
text:
Key Biological Findings

1Ô∏è‚É£ Endocannabinoid System Modulation
After ayahuasca intake:

‚Üë N-acyl-ethanolamines (e.g., anandamide, DGLEA)
‚Üì 2-acyl-glycerols (e.g., 2-AG) :contentReferenceoaicite:11

This indicates a strong modulation of the endocannabinoid system, a central regulator of mood, emotion and neuroplasticity.
Interestingly, several endocannabinoids were directly associated with alkaloid concentrations.



2Ô∏è‚É£ Large Neutral Amino Acid (LNAA) Imbalance
We observed:

‚Üì Tyrosine
Altered LNAA ratios
Changes in tryptophan-related pathways

Why does this matter?
LNAAs compete to cross the blood‚Äìbrain barrier.
Changes in their relative concentrations influence:

Serotonin synthesis (via tryptophan)
Dopamine synthesis (via tyrosine)

This suggests a neurochemical rebalancing between serotonergic and dopaminergic systems during the experience.

title: Psychedelic Integromics Research
text:
Linking Biology to Subjective Experience
The integrated network analysis revealed:

Strong associations between LNAA balance and 9 of 11 ASC subscales

Positive association of tryptophan/LNAA ratio with experiences of:

Unity
Blissful state
Insightfulness


Remarkably, these metabolic signatures were only moderately related to plasma DMT concentrations.
This suggests that:

The subjective psychedelic experience may be shaped more by systemic metabolic reconfiguration than by drug concentration alone.




Fig. 1. Heatmap analysis performed by using regularized canonical correlations analysis showing the relation between ayahuasca alkaloids and ayahuasca-subjective effects against metabolomic dataset, after the intake of ayahuasca. .

title: Psychedelic Integromics Research
text:
Systems-Level Interpretation
Enrichment analysis confirmed dysregulation in pathways involved in:

Serotonin synthesis

Dopamine metabolism

Endocannabinoid signalling

Together, the findings support a crosstalk between peripheral metabolism and central neurotransmission, revealing a specific metabolic fingerprint underlying the ayahuasca experience.



Fig. 2. Integrative network graph depicting correlations derived from regularized canonical correlation analysis between ayahuasca alkaloids, ayahuasca-induced subjective effects, metabolic markers and behavioural data. .

title: Psychedelic Integromics Research
text:
Scientific Rigor & Limitations

Naturalistic ceremonial setting
Single post-intake timepoint for alkaloids
Set and setting effects not experimentally controlled

Despite these limitations, this work provides the first human metabolomic framework for psychedelic research.

title: Psychedelic Integromics Research
text:
Why This Matters
Understanding the metabolic architecture of psychedelic states may:

Clarify mechanisms of therapeutic action
Identify biological markers of treatment response
Inform precision psychiatry approaches
Reveal systemic biomarkers beyond receptor pharmacology

This project sits at the intersection of:
Metabolomics ¬∑ Systems Biology ¬∑ Psychopharmacology ¬∑ Translational Psychiatry
